title: [nested-property] Prototype Pollution

profile.name: Node.js third-party modules
profile.about: This program is used to handle vulnerabilities in the Node.js ecosystem.

vulnerability_information:
Hi team,
I would like to report a prototype pollution vulnerability in nested-property
that allows an attacker to modify properties on Object.prototype.

Module name:nested-property
version: 1.0.4
npm page: https://www.npmjs.com/package/nested-property

Module Description
Read, write or test a data structure's nested property via a string like 'my.nested.property'. It works through arrays and objects.

 Module Stats

> Replace stats below with numbers from npm’s module page:

[1] weekly downloads :81,395

# Vulnerability

## Vulnerability Description
the vulnerabilty is similar to what  reported in https://hackerone.com/reports/719856
nestedproperty module  is vulnerable when it performs a set operation for nested objects

## Steps To Reproduce:


## Supporting Material/References:

var nestedProperty = require("nested-property");
const object = {};
object.b=true;
console.log("Before " + object.b); // will log true
nestedProperty.set(object, '__proto__.b', false);
console.log("After " + {}.b); // will log false

- [OPERATING SYSTEM VERSION] Ubuntu 16.04
- [NODEJS VERSION]  10.16
- [NPM VERSION] 6.90

# Wrap up

- I contacted the maintainer to let them know: N
- I opened an issue in the related repository: N 

> Hunter's comments and funny memes goes here

https://media1.tenor.com/images/dc2899b4432861e0ce1b9a03d8c98719/tenor.gif

## Impact

This might causes Denial of Service or RCE in some cases

Module name:nested-property
version: 1.0.4

activities.message:
Hi @johnssimon007,

while running your provided PoC I get the following output:

```
# node poc.js 
Before true
After undefined
```

this happens with both `2.0.0-beta1` which is the current default one, and `1.0.4`. Could you please double check?

Thanks,
@nochnoidozor

activities.markdown_message: i have tried this in both beta2.0.0 and default 1.0.4 as well.Both versions are vulnerable

Sorry for arising confusion. I found that i did a mistake when writing poc code .I didnt put it in code block .So the code changed to 'proto.b' instead of _ _ proto_ _.b,Which was the reason it shows undefined.For some reasons the _ seems to get stripped out from the report after submit

var nestedProperty = require("nested-property");
const object = {};
object.b=true;
console.log("Before " + object.b); // will log true
nestedProperty.set(object, '_ _ proto _ _.b', false);
console.log("After " + {}.b); // will log false

activities.message:
Hi,

thanks for reporting the issue, I'll suggest a fix shortly.
In the meantime, could you give me more details about how this vulnerability could be used for DOS or RCE?

Thanks!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi,

thanks for reporting the issue, I'll suggest a fix shortly.
In the meantime, could you give me more details about how this vulnerability could be used for DOS or RCE?

Thanks!

activities.message:
Also, what would be the preferred fix for this vulnerability to prevent DOS and RCE attacks?
1. prevent attempts to mutate `Object.prototype` (i.e. reject this: nestedProperty.set(Object.prototype, 'a', value))
2. prevent attempts to mutate AND read from `Object.prototype` (i.e: also reject this nestedProperty.get(Object.prototype, 'a'))

3. reject setting a property when `.__proto__` is present in the path (i.e reject this: `nestedProperty.set(anyObj, '*nested.__proto__.a', value)`)
4. reject setting and getting a property on any object in the prototype chain (only set, get on `own` properties)

I intended nested-property to be able to read from the prototype chain given that it's a valid ES feature, and I can't really prevent from mutating an object that is present in another object's prototype chain, but I would understand preventing mutations on `Object.prototype` (though it can still be achieved by other means) or having a "strict mode" that would throw an error when reading from `Object.prototype` because it's unsafe.

Thanks!
activities.markdown_message:
Also, what would be the preferred fix for this vulnerability to prevent DOS and RCE attacks?

  1. prevent attempts to mutate Object.prototype (i.e. reject this: nestedProperty.set(Object.prototype, 'a', value))

  2. prevent attempts to mutate AND read from Object.prototype (i.e: also reject this nestedProperty.get(Object.prototype, 'a'))

  3. reject setting a property when .__proto__ is present in the path (i.e reject this: nestedProperty.set(anyObj, '*nested.__proto__.a', value))

  4. reject setting and getting a property on any object in the prototype chain (only set, get on own properties)

I intended nested-property to be able to read from the prototype chain given that it's a valid ES feature, and I can't really prevent from mutating an object that is present in another object's prototype chain, but I would understand preventing mutations on Object.prototype (though it can still be achieved by other means) or having a "strict mode" that would throw an error when reading from Object.prototype because it's unsafe.

Thanks!

activities.message: Hello @podefr ,sorry for late reply.,The best way to mitigate this issue is to prevent writing to prototype as well as proto
activities.markdown_message: Hello @podefr ,sorry for late reply.,The best way to mitigate this issue is to prevent writing to prototype as well as proto

activities.message:
Object.freeze(Object.prototype);
Object.freeze(Object);


either freeze it or don't allow keywords like 

````
__proto__
prototype
constructor
```
activities.markdown_message:
Object.freeze(Object.prototype);
Object.freeze(Object);

either freeze it or don't allow keywords like 

__proto__
prototype
constructor

activities.message:
Hi, my turn to apologize for the delay.
I think that calling Object.freeze should be a decision made willingly by the library's user as opposed to being a side effect, if someone is actually exptecting proto to be extended then simply loading `nested-property` would break things in unexpected ways.
So I went with the solution of retrieving Object.prototype using reflection on a newly created object (`Reflect.getPrototypeOf({})`) and throwing an error if that's the object we're trying to mutate.

You can check the changes on this branch: `https://github.com/cosmosio/nested-property/tree/issue-788883`

If you checkout that branch, you can 
1. `npm run pack` and `npm install` the resulting `.tar.gz`
2. `npm run build` and import `dist/nested-property.js`
3. you can also run and play with the tests `npm run test`, I've added a test in `set.spec.js`: https://github.com/cosmosio/nested-property/blob/e592b23e0a771b8db74578464dc81374f4b5f1ab/test/set.spec.js#L388

let me know if this addresses the issue and I can make a new release.

Thanks!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi, my turn to apologize for the delay.
I think that calling Object.freeze should be a decision made willingly by the library's user as opposed to being a side effect, if someone is actually exptecting proto to be extended then simply loading nested-property would break things in unexpected ways.
So I went with the solution of retrieving Object.prototype using reflection on a newly created object (Reflect.getPrototypeOf({})) and throwing an error if that's the object we're trying to mutate.

You can check the changes on this branch: https://github.com/cosmosio/nested-property/tree/issue-788883

If you checkout that branch, you can

  1. npm run pack and npm install the resulting .tar.gz
  2. npm run build and import dist/nested-property.js
  3. you can also run and play with the tests npm run test, I've added a test in set.spec.js: https://github.com/cosmosio/nested-property/blob/e592b23e0a771b8db74578464dc81374f4b5f1ab/test/set.spec.js#L388

let me know if this addresses the issue and I can make a new release.

Thanks!
